Executive Summary
This document was developed to comply with the Environmental Protection AgencyÂ¿s (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) II, under Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 CFR Part 68. An outline of the RMP is provided in Figure ES-1. The chlorination and ammoniation systems are the processes covered under this regulation at Victoria Surface Water Treatment Plant (SWTP).

To meet the regulation requirements, this summary contains useful information on the chlorine and ammonia systems. The technical information herein may be used as a training reference in initial and recurring operator and maintenance training. Training on process fundamentals, operations, and maintenance, coupled with the recommended process modifications discussed below, will reduce the potential hazards to plant personnel and the surrounding community.
An Emergency Response Program and an Incident Investigation Program are included. These two programs should be an integral part of both initial and recurring training.
A Risk Management Plan (Plan), as required by the EPA, is included at the end of the main body of this document. It consists of a summary of data elements that must be submitted to the EPA that will eventually be uploaded onto a public access data base. The Plan has an Executive Summary that follows a required EPA format, and is intended to inform the public of Victoria SWTP's proactive stance toward protection of the environment and the surrounding community.

Hazard Assessment

The Hazard Assessment is comprised of a Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenario each

for the chlorine and anhydrous ammonia systems, as well as a 5-Year Accident History for the same.  The Hazard Assessment was conducted as an initial screening procedure as part of determining into which Program Level (I, II, or III) Victoria SWTP falls.  Residences lie within the EPA-defined endpoint concentrations of Victoria SWTP's Worst-Case release.  Therefore, the plant is ineligible for Program I.  Because Texas public utilities are currently excluded from Program III, Victoria SWTP is included in Risk Management Program II.  

Worst Case Scenarios
The Worst Case Scenario (WCS) was defined as a ton container (2,000 pounds) of chlorine being released by a catastrophic event within a 10-minute duration, and a 10,000 gallon tank (43,800 pounds) of anhydrous ammonia being released by a catastrophic event within a 10-minute duration.  A mitigation factor of 0.55 was allowed for the chlorine process due to the facility being enclosed in a building or a shed.  This chlorine scenario was developed and modeled using the EPA approved dense gas dispersion model DEGADIS 2.1. The toxic endpoint for chlorine was determined to be 1.55 miles.  The anhydrous ammonia scenario was developed using the EPA approved ALOHA Model Reference Tables.  The toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia was determined to be 2.48 miles.

Alternative Release Scenarios
The Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) of chlorine was modeled using DEGADIS 2.1. Source term estimations of approximately 175 pounds of chlorine gas released were derived from a scenario of a failed direct regulator connection. The dispersion model estimated the 3 ppm chlorine footprint to extend to 0.26 miles.  The anhydrous ammonia ARS was developed using the EPA approved ALOHA Model Reference Tables.  Source term estimations of approximately 84 pounds per minute of an anhydrous ammonia liquid/gas mixture released were derived from a scenario of a leak from a pipe or tank truck unloading hose protected by an excess flow valve.  The

dispersion model estimated the ammonia footprint to extend to 0.31 miles.

5 Year Accident History
No accidents have ever occurred at the facility involving either onsite or offsite consequences during the past five years.

Management Program
The Management Program consists of the Document Management System described below.

Document Management System
A Document Management System was established to attribute responsibility for the development, implementation, and maintenance of the Risk Management Program. The Program must be updated every three years, or any time a covered process undergoes a physical or administrative modification.  The Document Management System is largely a function of the Risk Management Program Team, described below in Table ES-2.

Risk Management Program Team
The following members are responsible for the Risk Management Program development, implementation, and maintenance. The Water Production Supervisor has the ultimate responsibility.

Prevention Program
The Prevention Program is more appropriately entitled the Accidental Release Prevention Program.  It is comprised of Safety Information, Hazard Review, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Incident Investigation, and 	Compliance Audit procedures.  Each has an entire chapter devoted to it in this RMP, and is described in more detail below.

Safety Information

Safety Information is divided between Chemical Safety Information, and Process Safety Information.  Each is described below.

Chemical Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data is provided in this section to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds;

health hazards, chemical exposure limitations and first aid; as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia. This information was compiled from numerous sources, and is intended to be a one-stop source for the reader seeking data on this substance. The physical data will provide useful information in the inevitable event the plant processes are modified, thereby requiring revisited dense gas dispersion modeling.

Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information was meticulously compiled on the chlorination and ammoniation systems.  Specifications on the process are collocated in one place for easy reference. Details such as Maximum Intended Inventory, Safe Upper and Lower Temperatures, Safe Upper and Lower Pressures, and Codes and Standards Used to Design, Build and Operate the Process are provided in this section.  Used as a training reference, together with the Process Schematic located in the Appendix, the reader will readily understand the function and operation of the chlorination system.

Hazard Review
A Hazard Review was conducted for the chlorination and ammoniation systems. The team consisted of facility management, process operating and maintenance experts, outside persons knowledgeable on chlorination system design, and consultants knowledgeable in the Hazard Review process itself. The Hazard Review technique used was a hybrid Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), in the form of a What If analysis. The What If was developed from HAZOP experience at similar treatment processes.

Recommendations
The result of the Hazard Review is a set of recommendations for the plant to implement. The Rule under 40 CFR 68.50 requires the City of Victoria to ensure that problems identified are resolved in a timely manner.  For those items that can not be promptly resolved, it is recommended that a schedule be developed that addresses those issues, with personnel responsibility assigned for each.  
Please note that these are not the reco

mmendations of Camp Dresser & McKee Inc.  Rather, they are recommendations developed by the Hazard Review Team with a consensus from the CityÂ¿s Team members.  CDM's role was simply to facilitate the Hazard Review process. 
The results of the Hazard Review were tabulated and a summary of the recommendations is provided below.  

Administrative and Operational Recommendations
Vendor audits were recommended to verify quality assurance and quality control on chlorine packaging.  The City of Victoria should be interested in container hydrostatic testing, and pre-shipment inspection.  Look for inspection reports from appropriate oversight agencies. 
If at all possible, it was recommended to investigate contractual control over the vendor. In other words, use contract language and specifications to ensure delivery of safe ton containers along with high-quality chlorine, as well safe delivery of high-quality ammonia.  This policy will hold the supplier responsible for liability and monetary damages associated with defective ton containers and / or poor quality chlorine or anhydrous ammonia.  
Ensure maintenance procedures are updated with operational inspections of equipment.  

Training Recommendations
Certain hazards reviewed can be mitigated through training. The following were highlighted during the Hazard Review as particularly important to operating / maintenance personnel, and the community.
Ensure CityÂ¿s Emergency Response policy is properly trained and implemented. Coordinate with the Fire Department to ensure they are adequately trained and equipped for a HazMat (chlorine and ammonia) response. Ensure select operators have adequate training to assist the Fire Department. Perform training drills onsite to ensure proper coordination.
Ensure maintenance technicians receive necessary job training such as Water Utilities Safety, Chlorinator Maintenance, Ammoniator Maintenance, and any other training that might be necessary to accomplish his work safely.
Ensure operat

ors know hazard exists of receiving defective ton containers that have developed cracks in the internal feed tube below the liquid level.
Ensure operators understand hazard of using direct heat on any part of the chlorination and ammoniation systems.
Ensure operators understand hazard associated with exposing oil, grease, petroleum products, or other combustibles to chlorine gas.  Use only approved lubricants on chlorination system.  Use good housekeeping in area, and store no combustibles around chlorination or ammoniation equipment.
Ensure ton container caps are in place before handling containers.
Ensure lines are evacuated prior to removing vacuum regulating check units.
Use buddy system during ton container changeover.  Ensure SCBA/airpacks are worn during this procedure.  
Ensure operators are properly trained on this policy.
Ensure all employees are familiar with the Hurricane Plan.  Review this plan annually.
Ensure all plant gates are locked when plants are unmanned.
